Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital after being struck by an auto
causing multiple injuries including  bleeding brain injury,
facial and jaw fractures, spine bone ftacture in your mid back
region, a liver laceration and broken wrist bones. You required
several operations to repair your broken face/jaw bones where
your jaw was wired. Your wrist fracture was also repaired and
you should avoid putting weight on your right wrist until you
have follow up with the Orthoepdic specialist who will upgrade
your weight bearing status.

*The wire cutters will need to stay at the bedside at all times
in the event of a respiratory emergency and/or if vomiting
occursthe wires should be cut.

Postoperative instructions following jaw surgery

Wound care: Do not disturb or probe the surgical area with any
objects. The sutures placed in your mouth are usually the type
that self dissolve. If you have any sutures on the skin of your
face or neck, your surgeon will remove them on the day of your
first follow up appointment. SMOKING is detrimental to healing
and will cause complications.

Bleeding: Intermittent bleeding or oozing overnight is normal.
Placing fresh gauze over the area and biting on the gauze for
30-45 minutes at a time may control the bleeding. If you had
nasal surgery, you may have occasional slow oozing from your
nostril for the first 2-3 days. Bleeding should never be severe.
If bleeding persists or is severe or uncontrollable, please call
our office immediately. If it is after normal business hours,
please come to the emergency room and request that the oral
surgery resident on call be paged.

Healing: Normal healing after oral surgery should be as follows:
the first 2-3 days after surgery, are generally the most
uncomfortable and there is usually significant swelling. After
the first week, you should be more comfortable. The remainder of
your postoperative course should be gradual, steady improvement.
If you do not see continued improvement, please call our office.

Physical activity: It is recommended that you not perform any
strenuous physical activity for a few weeks after surgery. Do
not lift any heavy loads and avoid physical sports unless you
obtain permission from your surgeon.

Swelling & Ice applications: Swelling is often associated with
surgery. Swelling can be minimized by using a cold pack, ice bag
or a bag of frozen peas wrapped in a towel, with firm
application to face and neck areas. This should be applied 20
minutes on and 20 minutes off during the first 2-3 days after
surgery. If you have been given medicine to control the
swelling, be sure to take it as directed.

Hot applications: Starting on the 3rd or 4th day after surgery,
you may apply warm compresses to the skin over the areas of
swelling (hot water bottle wrapped in a towel, etc), for 20
minutes on and 20 min off to help soothe tender areas and help
to decrease swelling and stiffness. Please use caution when
applying ice or heat to your face as certain areas may feel numb
after surgery and extremes of temperature may cause serious
damage.

Tooth brushing: Begin your normal oral hygiene the day after
surgery. Soreness and swelling may nor permit vigorous brushing,
but please make every effort to clean your teeth with the bounds
of comfort. Any toothpaste is acceptable. Please remember that
your gums may be numb after surgery. To avoid injury to the gums
during brushing, use a child size toothbrush and brush in front
of a mirror staying only on teeth.

Mouth rinses: Keeping your mouth clean after surgery is
essential. Use 1 teaspoon of salt dissolved in an 8 ounce glass
of warm water and gently rinse with portions of the solution,
taking 5 min to use the entire glassful. Repeat as often as you
like, but you should do this at least 4 times each day. If your
surgeon has prescribed a specific rinse, use as directed.

Showering: You may shower 1-2 days after surgery, but please ask
your surgeon about this. If you have any incisions on the skin
of your face or body, you should cover them with a water
resistant dressing while showering. DO NOT SOAK SURGICAL SITES.
This will avoid getting the area excessively wet. As you may
physically feel weak after surgery, initially avoid extreme hot
or cold showers, as these may cause some patients to pass out.
Also it is a good idea to make sure someone is available to
assist you in case if you may need help.

Sleeping: Please keep your head elevated while sleeping. This
will minimize swelling and discomfort and reduce pain while
allowing you to breathe more easily. One or two pillows may be
placed beneath your mattress at the head of the bed to prop the
bed into a more vertical position.

Pain: Most facial and jaw reconstructive surgery is accompanied
by some degree of discomfort. You will usually have a
prescription for pain medication. Some patients find that
stronger pain medications cause nausea, but if you precede each
pain pill with a small amount of food, chances of nausea will be
reduced. The effects of pain medications vary widely among
individuals. If you do not achieve adequate pain relief at first
you may supplement each pain pill with an analgesic such as
Tylenol or Motrin. If you find that you are taking large amounts
of pain medications at frequent intervals, please call our
office.
If your jaws are wired shut with elastics, you may have been
prescribed liquid pain medications. Please remember to rinse
your mouth after taking liquid pain medications as they can
stick to the braces and can cause gum disease and damage teeth.

Diet: Unless otherwise instructed, only a cool, clear liquid
diet is allowed for the first 24 hours after surgery. After 48
hours, you can increase to a full liquid diet, but please check
with your doctor before doing this. Avoid extreme hot and cold.
If your jaws are not wired shut, then after one week, you may be
able to gradually progress to a soft diet, but ONLY if your
surgeon instructs you to do so. It is important not to skip any
meals. If you take nourishment regularly you will feel better,
gain strength, have less discomfort and heal faster. Over the
counter meal supplements are helpful to support nutritional
needs in the first few days after surgery. A nutrition guidebook
will be given to you before you are discharged from the
hospital. Remember to rinse your mouth after any food intake,
failure to do this may cause infections and gum disease and
possible loss of teeth.

Nausea/Vomiting: Nausea is not uncommon after surgery. Sometimes
pain medications are the cause. Precede each pill with a small
amount of soft food. Taking pain pills with a large glass of
water can also reduce nausea. Try taking clear fluids and
minimizing taking pain medications, but call us if you do not
feel better. If your jaws are wired shut with elastics and you
experience nausea/vomiting, try tilting your head and neck to
one side. This will allow the vomitus to drain out of your
mouth. If you feel that you cannot safely expel the vomitus in
this manner, you can cut elastics/wires and open your mouth.
Inform our office immediately if you elect to do this. If it is
after normal business hours, please come to the emergency room
at once, and have the oral surgery on call resident paged.

Graft Instructions: If you have had a bone graft or soft tissue
graft procedure, the site where the graft was taken from (rib,
head, mouth, skin, clavicle, hip etc) may require additional
precautions. Depending on the site of the graft harvest, your
surgeon will [**Location (un) 8146**] you regarding specific instructions for
the care of that area. If you had a bone graft taken from your
hip, we encourage you to ambulate on the day of surgery with
assistance. It is important to start slowly and hold onto stable
structures while walking. As you progressively increase your
ambulation, the discomfort will gradually diminish. If you have
any problems with urination or with bowel movements, call our
office immediately.

Elastics: Depending on the type of surgery, you may have
elastics and/or wires placed on your braces. Before discharge
from the hospital, the doctor [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 8146**] you regarding these
wires/elastics. If for any reason, the elastics or wires break,
or if you feel your bite is shifting, please call our office.


Followup Instructions:
**You will be contact[**Name (NI) **] for an appointment with the Oral
[**Hospital 110270**] Clinic. If you do not receive a call by the end of
week please contact their office at [**Telephone/Fax (1) 110271**]

sections.Hospital Course:
Brief Hospital Course:
This is a 37 year old female with an unknown past medical
history found unresponsive in her car after vomiting surrounded
by pills with concern for suicide attempt with overdose.

# Unresponsiveness - Felt to be most likely secondary to
anticholinergic toxicity from benedryl overdose and alcohol. She
was intubated for airway protection at OSH after seizure in the
setting of unresponsiveness. She was extubated the next morning
([**2144-2-9**]) without complications. Lactate has normalized.
Although she complained of some visual hallucinations early in
the day (likely secondary to benadryl overdose) she remained
alert and oriented throughout the day.  She was transferred to
the medicine floor on [**2-10**] and did very well.  She remained AAO x
3 with no other hallucinations.  Anxiety was managed with
lorazepam .5-1mg PO q4-6hrs PRN.

# Overdose, suicide attempt, severe depression - Felt to be a
suicide attempt.  Received charcoal at the OSH.  Evaluated by
toxicology in the ED with concern for benadryl overdose and
anticholinergic syndrome, though patient no longer tachycardic.
Utox and serum tox unrevealing except for alcohol (benzos likely
secondary to ativan given for seizure at OSH).  Noteably
negative for acetaminophen and tricyclics. Serial EKGs to
monitor for QTC prolongation, remained stable, last check at
421. Psych said she cannot leave AMA and if wants to leave needs
to be Section 12. Patient received 24hour 1:1 sitter while here.
 She was transferred to the medicine floor and was medically
cleared to be discharged to a [**Hospital 86111**] hospital for inpatient
therapy.  Patient was sent to [**Hospital **] Hospital on discharge.

# Pneumonia, aspiration: Pt spiked a fever to 101.4 on [**2-9**]. Pan
cultured and CXR performed. In setting of possible infiltrate,
pt was started on augmentin for possible aspiration PNA.  The
following morning, sputum gram stain was positive for coag
positive staph, and the patient was switched to PO clindamycin
which was thought to cover community acquired MRSA and
anaerobes. Upon transfer to the medicine floor, she was switched
to IV vanc given temp of 101.2 and white count of 18.5.  No
organism or sensitivites were available at that point.  She
remained afebrile after transfer to the medicine floor.
Cultures showed pan-sensitive staph aureus (coag +).  She was
transitioned back to PO clindamycin (300mg q6hr) and did well.
Last day of antibiotics will be [**2144-2-16**].

FEN: She initially received IVF boluses prn to maintain urine
output (rec'd IVF at OSH and 1L in [**Hospital1 18**] ED).

Prophylaxis: Subutaneous heparin, bowel regimen

Access: peripherals

Mrs. [**Known lastname 47400**] is a 37 year old female with an unknown past medical
history who was found in her car on the side of the road
unresponsive earlier today.  Per report she had vomited and was
surrounded by little pink pills and had sent suicidal text
messages on her cell phone (no damage to car).  She was
initially transported to [**Hospital 8641**] Hospital where she was initially
noted to withdraw to painful stimuli and then had a seizure that
lasted 1 minute and resolved with ativan 2 mg.  She was
intubated for decreased responsiveness and airway protection.
She was tachycardic to the 120s.  She had a CT head, C-spine,
and torso that were reportedly negative.  Alcohol level was 166.
 Utox was negative.  She also received narcan without effect,
activated charcoal, and protonix.
.

99% intubated.  Propofol was turned off and after five minutes
she was noted to withdraw from pain and spontaneously move her
right upper extremity.  Reflexes were normal.  Labs were notable
for serum alcohol level of 15, utox + benzodiazepines and ABG
7.46/32/429.  EKG with QTc 465 and rate 80.  Toxicology was
consulted and felt the ingestion may have been benadryl with
anticholinergic intoxication syndrome although the patient was
no longer tachycardic.  They recommended supportive care and
monitoring QRS interval.  At time of sign-out patient was on
propofol at a rate of 40 and noted to be following commands.

sections.Hospital Course:
Brief Hospital Course:
70 yo m with hx of dialated ischemic cardiomyopathy with an EF
of 20% who was admitted for an elective repair of a left
nonunion subtrochanteric femur fracture who had hypotension and
a PEA arrest with induction of anesthesia.
.
# PEA arrest/hypoxia: occured in setting of placing a central
line. Pt became hypotensive, may have had a vagal event. Also
may having been having hypoxia that could have contributed. ABG
on arrival to ICU was 7.2/53/76 on FiO2 80%. CXR with possible
effusion on left and pulm edema. IP was consulted but did not
recommend tapping the pleural fluid. He was weaned and extubated
on [**2112-2-24**] and did not require further ventilatory support.
.
# CAD: hx of recent angioplasty to Lcx [**12-22**], was on plavix
since. No reported recent CP. Pt may have had demand ischemia
due to hypotension/PEA arrest and afib with RVR. His CE were
trended but negative for ACS and his lipitor/ASA/Metoprolol were
 restarted.
.
# CHF: Pt has a hx of dilated ischemic cardiomyopathy with an EF
of 20%. CXR showed pulm edema. Lasix gtt was stated with goal
-1L per day but stopped on [**2112-2-24**] as patient appeared
euvolemic. Given the low EF, afterload reduction was achieved
with ACE-i, BB and lasix gtt. On the day of discharge, he
appeared euvolemic with Cr at baseline and minimal crackles on
exam without O2 requirement.
.
# RHYTHM: had afib with RVR post PEA arrest, now s/p
cardioversion and is v-paced. BP improved with cardioversion.
Had TEE with no thrombus in OR, and will need to be
anticoagulated. Pt has a hx of some compliance issues with
coumadin per OMR. His coumadin was continued with INR goal [**12-31**].
He was also continued on his home dose of digoxin 0.125mg.
.
# Chest pain: thought to be [**12-30**] CPR, CE were flat, was on
tylenol and given a dose of morphine however he became delirious
with medication and further pain control was achieved with
Tylenol and Toradol. He pain waxed and waned over the course of
his admission but had essentially disappeared on discharge.
.
# Abdominal pain: Patient with increasing abdominal pain during
his CCU stay with increased T-bili (although AST/ALT nl). He
underwent Abdominal U/S on [**2112-2-28**] that revealed moderate ascites
and biliary sludge. A paracentesis was attempted but not
performed [**12-30**] the small amount of ascitic fluid on repeat U/S.
His pain decreased over the the course of his stay and was well
controlled with tramadol and occasional toradol.  On discharge
he had only mild discomfort with no peritoneal signs.

# Diarrhea: Patient had c-diff sent but was not positive. His
bowel regimen was held and this symptom gradually improved
during his hospitalization.

# HTN: BP was normotensive off pressors in the first 48hrs post
PEA arrest and treated thereafter with [**Last Name (un) **] (valsartan) which was
intermittently held for low SBP 80-90s.

# UTI: patient developed fevers with a positive U/A, he was
treated with Bactrim that was changed to Cefpodoxime for total
course of 7 days.
.
# HLD: stable and chronic, he was continued on lipitor
.
# DMII: stable, pt maintained on NPH 15 units [**Hospital1 **] with SSI with
humalog
.
# CRF: baseline Cr is 1.2. Pt was thought to be at risk for ATN
due to hypotension. His Cr/UOP were trended and Cr returned
close to baseline prior to discharge.
.
# Depression/Mental status: Patient was continued on home SSRI,
he became agitated on [**2112-2-24**] [**12-30**] morphine and require a dose of
zydis 5mg. Several family meetings were undertaken to better
define his goals of care and personal wishes regarding end-of
life issues and comfort care.

sections.History of Present Illness:
History of Present Illness:
70 yo m with hx of dilated ischemic CM with EF of 20%, who was
in the OR today for an elective repair of his left hip non-[**Hospital1 **]
fx and he had hypotension and a PEA arrest in the setting of
anesthesia induction. After he was intubated he had a CVL placed
and became hypotensive. He was given IVF and neo, then changed
to epi. He then had a PEA arrest for about 1 minute with
compressions and was given epi bolus x 1 with a return of a
pulse. He was continued on a epi gtt. He was then in afib with
RVR HR in 120s. EP was called and then interogated his
pacemaker, did a TEE with no thrombus, and he was cardioverted
with 100 J x 1, and then 200 J x 1 to a paced rhythm. He also
had hypoxia with low saturations during the above event
requiring FiO2 of 100%. He had reported pleural effusions on his
echo. The OR team attempted to place a CT on the left, but were
unable to due to adhesions. His inital ABG post arrest was pH
7.07 pCO2 78 pO2 62. No CXR was done prior to transfer. Pt was
also given Vecuronium x 1 in the OR. Pt was given 1500ml IVF
total per anesthesia.

Of note he had many admissions over the last calendar year for
difficult to control CHF. His last admission was on [**2111-12-22**] at
which time he had a Cath with a angioplasty to his Lcx and was
started on plavix.

ROS, unable to complete due sedation.

chronic non-healing ulcers [**3-1**] heroin use. Though pt reports not
having used heroin in the past 6 months, ulcers have not healed
despite dressing changes at home. On admission, ulcers appeared
infected and pt was febrile. Pt was started on IV nafcillin for
MSSA, to complete a total 6-week course. Of note, pt has history
of MSSA infections in the past (abscesses, bacteremia, and R
sided endocarditis) for which she completed nafcillin courses.
Pt also had history of thoracic osteomyelitis in [**2144**] treated at
[**Hospital1 2025**], though this was considered as possible source of bacteremia
on this admission, it seems less likely given no clinical
symptoms of back pain and more likely source of ulcers. Pt
refused MRI imaging, but should consider outpatient open MRI if
does not continue to have improvement. All surveillance cultures
since admission have had no growth to date. As described below,
pt was found to have aortic valve vegetation and infective
endocarditis with no abscess seen on TEE.
.
# Endocarditis - in setting of MSSA bacteremia, pt was found to
have 1.4cm vegetation on aortic valve, new since echo in [**3-9**],
with moderate aortic insufficiency. Started on 6-week course of
IV nafcillin as above. Cardiology and CT surgery were consulted
and did not recommend acute surgical intervention given
bacteremia and no decompensated heart function. Daily ECGs did
not show any abnormalities, pt had hypotension to SBP 100
throughout most of hospital stay and one episode of fever to
100.5 a week into therapy; given this, a TEE was done to
evaluate for cardiac abscess and was negative for this.
-Patient was transferred into MICU after code was called on
floors for hypoxic respiratory failure.  This respiratory
failure was quickly reversed with diuresis and NIMV, and was
thought to be [**3-1**] severe aortic valve insufficiency in the
setting of patient anxiety.  Similar episodes occurred
intermittently in the ICU with any mild increase in SVR, so
patient was kept with sedative/opiate regimen to stave off
anxiety.  Cardiac surgery was consulted, and it was agreed that
surgical correction of valve was only viable therapeutic option.
.
# Inguinal ulcers - [**3-1**] long-standing heroin use though pt
reports no use for past 6 months. She had been doing daily
dressing changes at home though these ulcers were likely
infected on admission (6x6cm in L anterior thigh area, 2x2cm in
R). Wound care and plastic surgery were consulted, plastic
surgery did not recommend surgical debriding, pt had wet-to-dry
dressing changes three times a day which required 1mg IV
dilaudid for pain control beforehand. Once pt completes
antibiotic course for bacteremia and endocarditis, she will
follow up with plastic surgery to consider flap placement to
ensure healing. Pt had bilateral venous stasis changes and 1+
edema below knees, in addition to leg elevation and
betamethasone cream, she was diuresed with lasix and had
decrease in edema and pain in legs.
.
# Acute renal insufficiency - likely pre-renal given poor PO
intake recently and infection. Cr improved to 1.3 today, FeNa
2.5% and FeUrea 52% both of which suggest resolution of
pre-renal state
- encourage PO intake
- continue to trend Cr
.
# Hypotension - now improved, SBP 110s-120s. Given aortic valve
vegetation, will maintain high suspicion for valve dysfunction
contributing to hypotension.
- encourage PO intake
- monitor on tele, daily ECGs
- continue abx as above
.
# Anemia - chronic, HCT baseline 26-27, [**Month/Day (2) **] studies in [**2145**]
revealed likely etiology as anemia of chronic inflammation. [**Year (4 digits) **]
panel indicates likely ACI, no evidence for hemolysis. HCT
bumped appropriately to 1U RBC. HCT stable today.
- T+S, PIV
- peripheral smear - no schistocytes
- B12 / folate - normal
.
# Anxiety - continue home 1mg TID ativan
.
# HCV - "inactive", never treated for this. Pt had liver biopsy
in [**6-6**] which showed fibrosis with no clear etiology for
hepatomegaly. She follows in [**Hospital **] clinic here. Recent poor
appetite and weight loss is concerning for malignancy, though
AFP not elevated.
- outpt work-up for ?malignancy
- LFTs stable

# IVDU - pt reports being clean for 6 months
- social work

 is 46 yo F with hx of IVDU, HCV, granulomatous disease of GI
tract, liver, spleen, and bone, hx of cellulitis, osteomyelitis

leg pain, right worse than left, bilateral leg swelling that
feel hot to touch. She was in her usual state of health until 2
days ago when she noticed that her R leg was painful and
swollen, she took 6 Advil for pain relief which did not help.
Measured her fever at home to be 103. Yesterday, she began to
notice swelling and pain in her L leg. No recent trauma in the
area, no open cuts or wounds preceding swelling. She was seen
yesterday at OSH where she was advised to be admitted for
antibiotics, she left AMA because she had a negative experience
during an admission last year. Did not get any antibiotics PO on
discharge. Last night, she used a pin to put a hole in her R leg
in hopes of relieving pressure, noticed minimal clear drainage
from the area. Of note, pt has chronic venous stasis changes
with erythema on R leg. Also has large ulcers in inguinal areas
L>R (6cm ulcer with pus and drainage in L inguinal area, 1cm
ulcer in R), she does dressing changes for these daily at home
using Silvedene. Inguinal ulcers are [**3-1**] heroin injection, pt
reports she has not injected in about 6 months and ulcers have
improved since then. She never injected in her toes, has not
injected in arms in many years due to scarring. Pt says she was
tested for HIV since stopping drugs and has been negative, HCV
infection is "inactive" per her, she was never treated for this.
.

vancomycin.

Cardiac Surgery Course:
The patient was brought to the operating room on [**2146-12-21**] where
the patient underwent aortic valve replacement with 23mm Porcine
tissue valve.  Overall the patient tolerated the procedure well
and post-operatively was transferred to the CVICU in stable
condition for recovery and invasive monitoring.  The patient
remained intubated on POD 1 as she had no cuff leak and had been
intubated multiple times during this admission, and it was
decided to manage her conservatively.  She remained on
epinephrine and propofol drips. Decadron was initiated for lack
of cuff leak on POD 2.
POD 3 found the patient extubated, alert and oriented and
breathing comfortably.  The patient was neurologically intact
and hemodynamically stable, weaned from inotropic and
vasopressor support.  Acute pain service was consulted, as she
has a h/o IVDA and refused MS Contin or Oxycontin.
Recommendations were made for dilaudid.  ID continued to follow
and the patient is to be maintained on Nafcillin for a 6 week
course through [**2147-1-9**].  PICC was placed to facilitate therapy.
 Fluconazole was initiated for yeast in the urine.  Beta blocker
was initiated and the patient was gently diuresed toward the
preoperative weight.  The patient was transferred to the
telemetry floor for further recovery.  Chest tubes and pacing
wires were discontinued without complication.  The patient was
evaluated by the physical therapy service for assistance with
strength and mobility.  By the time of discharge on POD 5, the
patient was ambulating freely, the wound was healing and pain
was controlled with oral analgesics.  The patient was discharged
to [**Hospital1 **], [**Location (un) 701**] in good condition with
appropriate follow up instructions.

sections.Hospital Course:
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. [**Known lastname 88418**] [**Last Name (Titles) 1834**] emergent exploratory laparotomy,
evacuation of hematoma, and resection of segment 5 of the liver.
Patient tolerated the procedure well, but was slow to wean off
anesthesia and was transferred to the SICU intubated. Patient
was extubated without difficulty shortly thereafter. The
remainder of his course is described below by relevant systems:
1. GI: Patient's postoperative recovery was uncomplicated. He
tolerated clear liquids on POD#2 and a regular diet on POD#3. He
passed flatus and had a bowel movement prior to discharge. LFTs
trended down daily during hospitalization. Intraoperatively,
patient's liver appeared Cirrhotic, and work up revealed
positive Hepatitis C ab. Patient was negative for HIV and Hep B.
Viral loads were sent but were pending at the time of discharge.
Patient was set up with an outpatient Hepatology appointment for
further management of newly diagnosed Hep C. On the day of
discharge, patient's pathology returned with evidence of
moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma with negative
margins. Further management will be discussed at the patient's
follow up appointment in one week.
2. Renal/GU: Patient's urine output was decreased with mild
hypotension (SBP 80s and 90s) in the SICU postoperatively.
Patient was resuscitated with fluids and urine ourput and blood
pressure normalized. Patient was given 20 mg lasix IV once on
POD#4 for LE edema with good response. Foley was removed on
POD#4 and the patient was unable to void thereafter. Foley was
replaced and flomax was started. Patient was able to void
without foley on day of discharge with PVR of 250 cc. CT pelvis
on [**11-25**] demonstrated enlarged prostate with ?nodule on the
left. Patient will follow up with Urology as an outpatient for
further evaluation, PSA was pending at time of discharge.
3. CV: Patient was hypertensive with SBP 170-190s on POD#3. BP
normalized with 20 of IV lasix and 25 metoprolol [**Hospital1 **]. Patient
was discharged home with po lopressor and will follow up with a
new PCP for management of his underlying hypertension.

Prior to discharge, patient was counseled by social work and
case management regarding at home support. Patient was
discharged home with nursing care, access to meals on wheels,
and with committments from friends for assistance once home. The
patient's daughter will be helping him at home for the first few
days as well.

sections.Hospital Course:
Brief Hospital Course:
86 F with history of esophageal and squamous cell lung cancer,
admitted for paliative esophageal stent placement complicated by
aspiration pneumonia.

# shortness of breath - initially attributed to an aspiration
pneumonia, this occured in the setting of esophageal stent
placement. She was started on treatment with levofloxacin and
flagyl on [**8-26**] and completed a 8 9 day course.  Given this
aspiration occured she was evaluated by speech and swallow and
recommended thin liquids and regular diet.  She continued to
have shortness of breath over the course of [**8-7**].  CTA
revealed a large left pleural effusion.  She received IVF fluids
on [**8-31**] for orthostasis and again on [**9-1**] for frank hypotension
felt [**3-9**] dehydration.  In this setting, concern was raised for
volume overload.  She was treated by optimizing rate control,
and gentle IV lasix on [**9-3**].  Her dyspnea was not markedly
changed with lasix, and her atrial fibrillation and hyponatremia
worsened.
.
Given poor response to lasix, and ongoing tachypnea (with
negative CTA), discussion was held over the possibility of
therapeutic thoracentesis.  The effusion is new as it was not
present on prior CXR on [**2111-8-14**] with her oncologist.  After
discussion with her oncologist ([**Last Name (un) 82949**] Anamur, [**Telephone/Fax (1) 82950**]),
this effusion was felt to be malignant (her lung ca is located
in the LUL and had improved s/p XRT), and felt likely to
reaccumulate.  Her prognosis was felt to be poor given 2 primary
malignancies, and her inability to tolerate chemotherapy.
.
After extensive discussion with the patient, her daughter [**Name (NI) **]
(HCP), the patient declined thoracentesis, and elected to change
goals of care to comfort measures only.  She was treated with
oral ativan and morphine for respiratory comfort.  She will be
discharged to hospice.  She may receive lasix prn dyspnea,
however these efforts have been limited by tachycardia and
hypotension during this hospitalization.
.
On the day of discharge, the above plan was again communicated
to the patient, and her son-in-law [**Name (NI) **] (alternate HCP) as her
daughter [**Name (NI) **] was not available.
.
# dizziness - pt complained of dizziness after starting
antibiotics.  her neurologic exam was non-focal.  head CT was
unremarkable for metastasis.  she demonstrated no nystagmus or
evidence of BPPV.  her dizziness was attributed to orthostasis
and medication.  her neurontin, percoceet and flagyl were
discontinued with mild improvement in her symptoms.  she is
being discharged to hospice with prn meclezine.
.
# diarrhea - likely [**3-9**] antibiotics, and improving at the time
of discharge.  she had stool cultures x3 negative for cdiff, and
general stool culture negative on [**9-2**].  she will be discharged
with prn lomotil.
.
#. Atrial fibrilation: Pt is rate controlled on dilt and amio at
home, though she is not anticoagulated.  She had intermittent
episodes of breakthrough RVR in 120-130s in the icu thought
likely due to underlying aspiration PNA and hypoxia.  She
remained asymptomatic with the RVR, diltiazem regimen was
titrated up and metoprolol was added to acheive better rate
control.  Her heart rate ranges between 80-120 on this regimen
and BP remains stable.  She did develop pleural effusions in
this setting requiring intermittent diuresis, as above.
.
She is being discharged to hospice on her regimen of metoprolol,
diltiazem, and amiodarone for comfort, as she becomes anxious
when she senses a rapid heart rate.
.
#. Esophageal + Lung Ca: pt with 2 primary malignancies,
including T3N1 esophageal  adenocarcinoma, with squamous cell
lung cancer s/p XRT, both diagnosed in [**2110**].  She is not a
chemotherapy candidate per discussion with her oncology provider
(above).  She received a palliative esophageal stent placement.
.
As above, she is being discharged to hospice given large left
pleural effusion and ongoing dyspnea

#. Depression: She is continued on home citalopram.

#. Post herpetic neuralgia: She had herpes zoster 7 weeks prior
with residual pain. She had sedation/somnolence on neurontin so
this was held, and liquid percocet was attempted.  Given ongoing
dizziness, neurontin and percocet were discontinued with some
improvement.  Her pain was controlled with tylenol.  She will be
discharged to hospice with morphine as above.
.
#. Hypertension: Previously hypertensive, for which she was
continued on diltiazem, up titrated as above with metoprolol for
rate control.  She subsequently was treated with IVF for
hypotension felt likely [**3-9**] dehydration and poor po intake.

#. COPD: She only uses albuterol at home.
#. GERD: continue PPI for comfort.
#. Hyperlipidemia: simvastatin was discontinued.
.
# CODE STATUS - pt made DNR/DNI after extensive discussion with
family and patient. she is being discharged to hospice with
comfort measures only, and understands no further role for
hospitalization as she is not interested in thoracentesis or
further surgical procedures to treat her malignancy, and is not
a chemotherapy candidate.
.

History of Present Illness:
86 year-old female with a history of esophageal ca who was
admitted from EGD suite after esophageal stent placement. The
patient last received radiation to her esophagus on [**2111-3-13**]. The
procedure was performed under MAC and complicated post-op by one
episode of desaturation to 89% and resp rate of 34 at the end of
the procedure. Patient was placed on O2 mask with 100% O2 and
saturationg increased to 98%. She was [**Last Name (un) 25177**] given an albuterol
neb. There was a question of possible aspiration during the
procedure. She was aggressively suctioned with mainly clear
secreations, but some "bilious" tinge per report. She was placed
on 6L NC. She became nauseous and vomited small amount bile and
given 4mg zofran IV. She remained in a-fib with HR in the 100's
post-op. BP 181/96 and 94% 10L O2, RR: 25 in the PACU. She was
transferred to the ICU for closer monitoring overnight.

constipation, melena, hematochezia, chest pain, orthopnea, PND,
lower extremity edema, cough, urinary frequency, urgency,
dysuria, lightheadedness, gait unsteadiness, focal weakness,
vision changes, headache, rash or skin changes.

sections.Hospital Course:
Brief Hospital Course:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

#.AORTIC STENOSIS ([**Location (un) 109**] 0.8cm2): enrolled in [**Location (un) 10723**]/TAVI study
high risk arm with randomization to TAVI. PPM interrogation was
unremarkable. The patient did receive his beta blocker the night
before the implantation on [**2112-2-23**]. The patient was also plavix
loaded with 300mg prior to the procedure. The patient tolerated
the procedure well and post-procedure echo showed resolution of
aortic stenosis with a well-seated valve, with an EF of 55%. He
was completely asymptomatic from a cardiovascular standpoint
upon discharge.

# NYHA CLASS IV DIASTOLIC CHF: Patient has hypertrophic
cardiomyopathy, with moderate-severe R dCHF, moderate L dCHF.
During his last admission, he was diuresed with Lasix 40mg IV
bolus once, and achieved euvolemia. Home torsemide and
metoprolol were continued. Patient is on home O2 (2L per NC) at
night, and continued this during hospitalization. Diuresed as
necessary to achieve euvolemia.
.
# CAD: Pt is s/p stent to LAD and D1 ([**4-/2106**]) and s/p diagonal
stent ([**2106**]). Most recent cath at [**Hospital1 18**] ([**11/2111**]) revealed no
obstructive CAD.
- continue home metoprolol tartrate 25mg PO bid, pravastatin
20mg daily and ASA 81mg. ASA increased to 325mg for TAVI
procedure.

# Atrial Flutter: Pt has history of AFlutter s/p ablation, then
tachy-brady s/p PPM. Also has history of chronic AFib, for which
he was just switched to pradaxa from coumadin. We continued home
digoxin 0.125 and home metoprolol tartrate 25 [**Hospital1 **]. He did have a
bit of oozing from his left groin site, this was fixed with
local lido/epi and pressure bandages. Given his several
hospitalizations for epistaxis we discussed the risk benefit of
anticoagulation with his hematologist/oncologist Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 4223**],
who agreed with us that given his CHADS2 score of 4 with an
annual stroke rate of 8% and no major bleeds, anticoaggulation
would still be indicated, and the patient agreed with this plan.
He was continued on warfarin.
.
# Diarrhea: Patient initially presented with nausea, vomitting
and diarrhea. C diff toxin was negative. His symptoms were
thought to be due to a viral gastrointestinal syndrome and
resolved with supportive measures prior to his procedure.

# Anemia: Patient with a clear iron deficiency anemia on labs
from [**2112-2-9**] (iron of 31, ferritin of 26, TIBC of 463). Patient
has a recent GI bleed admission in [**2109**] with stable HCTs and
colonscopy being a poor study but EGD showing erosive gastritis.
The patient showed no signs of GI bleed during his
hospitalization. He received 1 unit of PRBCs for a HCT of 25.5,
and discharge HCT was 28. The patient's PCP will be notified of
his anemia and that a screening colonoscpy (given the poor
study) would be indicated in the future.

# HTN: continued home metoprolol, as per above.
.
# HLD: continued home pravastatin.
.
#.OSA: pt has been on CPAP. PFTs actually show more of a
restrictive pattern. He is on home O2 at night, which was
continued during hospitalization. We continued 2L home O2 and
CAP nightly.
.
#.CKD: baseline creatinine 1.2, stable throughout last
hospitalization. Creatinine remained stable at 0.8 upon
discharge.
.
#.NIDDM: diet-controlled. Check qachs finger sticks, and
continued ISS. Blood sugars remained in the 100s throughout his
hospital stay.
.
#.BPH: continued home finasteride and tamsulosin
.
#.SPINAL STENOSIS: pt is s/p multiple interventions. Continued
gabapentin 100mg PO TID and tylenol 650mg PO q6 hrs PRN pain
.
#.GERD: continued home pantoprazole
.
#.MRSA old wound and sputum: contact precautions were in place.
muciprocin [**Hospital1 **]
and chlorhexidine skin prep/shower was initiated.
.
# Anemia of chronic renal disease: received Procrit 10,000 units

s/c on [**2-12**]. Transfused 2u PRBC [**2-19**] at [**Hospital1 18**] [**Location (un) 620**].
Transfused 1 unit PRBCs at [**Hospital1 18**].

sections.History of Present Illness:
History of Present Illness:
Mr. [**Known lastname 10722**] is an 84-year-old gentleman with a history of CAD
s/p LAD stenting in [**2105**], who has known diastolic heart failure
with a normal LVEF (70%). He also has a history of tachy-brady
syndrome and underwent a permanent pacemaker
placement. In [**Month (only) 1096**], was admitted to [**Hospital3 **] with
dyspnea and treated for a presumed CHF exacerbation. Trop at OSH
was 0.07 (indeterminate) and had increased O2 requirement. He
was transferred to [**Hospital1 18**] for cardiac catheterization which
revealed nonobstructive CAD. He was evaluated for aortic valve
treatment options. After informed consent including full
explanation of risks vs. benefits, he was enrolled into the high
risk arm of the [**Hospital1 10723**]/TAVI study. He met all inclusion
criteria, and did not meet any exclusion criteria, was screened
and accepted to be randomized to either [**Hospital1 10723**]/TAVI or
surgical AVR as per study protocol.
Patient was admitted from [**2112-2-7**] - [**2112-2-12**] for optimization of
cardiac status prior to randomization in [**Month/Day/Year 10723**] study.
Patient was randomized into [**Month/Day/Year **] arm, which he will receive
during this hospitalization.  During te last hospitalization, he
was started on Pradaxa in preparation for procedure. Patient
given clear instructions to stop taking Pradaxa 3 days prior to
procedure (on [**2112-2-20**]). He was also diuresed with lasix and
achieved euvolemia, maintained on 2L oxygen, which he is on at
home.

Since his last discharge, patient has been feeling well.  He had
one episode of severe epistaxis requiring packing by an ENT at
[**Hospital 882**] Hospital.  Per the patient, Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] was aware of this
and oversaw his care, and his pradaxa dose was decreased.
Patient stopped taking pradaxa the day prior to admission in
anticipation of [**Last Name (STitle) **] procedure.  Patient has not had any
more episodes of epistaxis since then.

Additionally, while receiving 2 units of pRBC at [**Location (un) 620**] on
[**2-19**], he developed abdominal pain which he thought was reflux,
but was not relieved by tums.  He was admitted for cardiac
enzyme monitoring, out of concern abd pain could be cardiac in
etiology.  Troponins were trended and were 0.074, then 0.102,
then 0.121. CK-MB flat.  Subsequently, he developed diarrhea,
[**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Location (un) 620**] report 10 episodes in one day.  Patient reports
diarrhea has improved and he now has 1-2 episodes of loose
stool.  He endorses a decreased appetite, but denies
nausea/vomiting.  C. diff was negative.

70 yo M w CAD s/p distant stenting on aspirin and Plavix,
osteoarthritis on significant NSAIDs who presented with massive
gastrointestinal hemorrhage.

#GI Bleed:  Patient required significant blood transfusion at
[**Hospital3 2783**] despite not being hemodynamically stable.
EGD was notable for non-bleeding antral ulcer. Colonoscopy at
OSH without source of bleeding. Tagged RBC scan upon transfer to
[**Hospital1 18**] was negative. He received 4 additional units of blood and
hematocrit was stable since [**7-4**] around 30. He had a capsule
endscopy which showed no evidence of small bowel bleeding
source. He was maintained on oral PPI [**Hospital1 **] and aspirin and Plavix
were held in consultation with patient's Cardiologist at
[**Hospital3 2783**]. After negative capsule, identified antral
ulcer, and having stable hematocrit patient was dischared on
oral PPI therapy with instructions not to resume Plavix and to
wait on restarting aspirin until discussion in two weeks with
Cardiology, GI, and PCP. [**Name10 (NameIs) 6**] [**Name Initial (NameIs) **]. pylori serology was also sent on
this admission, the result of which was pending at the time of
discharge. Patient's PCP was made aware of this lab pending at
discharge. Patient was also given explicit instructions not to
use NSAIDs. Patient will follow up in 2 weeks with either [**Hospital1 18**]
GI or [**Hospital1 2436**] GI, to be determined by the patient.

#OA: Patient was taking significant amounts of NSAIDs for his
osteoarthritic pain. Since he cannot take NSAIDs in the near
future he was discharged to use Tylenol prn for pain and
oxycodone prn for severe pain with long term pain control to be
determined by the patient's PC.

#CAD: ASA and Plavix were held. As above patient dischared off

be restarted in the future on the background of high dose PPI.
Patient was also restarted on his home ACEI prior to discharge.

complain of chest pain or shortness of breath.

lower dose of Lantus with instructions to titrate according to

sections.Hospital Course:
Brief Hospital Course:
Mrs. [**Known lastname **] is a pleasant 74yo female with history of
hypertension, distant history of IV drug use complicated by
endocarditis, Hepatitis C presenting with hypotension and
abdominal pain.
.
# Hypotension - The patient was admitted with a blood pressure
74/53.  Antihypertensives were held.  The patient received 6-7L
total in the ED and on admission to the ICU.  During her course
in the ICU, her blood pressure improved.  Hypotension may be
multifactorial including continuing blood pressure medication
usage in setting of hypovolemia from poor PO intake. She
underwent ECHO for a cardiac source of hypotension, but was
found to have normal biventricular function.  AM cortisol level
was normal, making adrenal insufficiency an unlikely source of
her hypotension.  She was started on vancomycin and zosyn for
broad spectrum coverage for possible sepsis. She was then
transferred to the general medicine floor afebrile and without
an elevated WBC count.
Upon admission to the general medicine floor, her hypotension
was resolved. Her antibiotics were discontinued when it was
determined that she was unlikely to have sepsis. Her blood
pressure remained in the 130s-160s/80s-100s. She was maintained
on diltiazem 45mg PO QID for the remainder of her admission.
Her blood pressure eventually stabilized in the 120s/80s.
.
#Abdominal pain - Patient complained of abdominal pain of
approximately 2 months' duration, diffuse, throughout the
abdomen, but not radiating elsewhere. During her admission on
the general medicine floor, she also began complaining of sharp
epigastric and RUQ tenderness, without radiation. Her abdomen
was distended and tympanitic. She had bilateral CVA tenderness.
Pancreatic enzymes were only mildly elevated, AST/ALT/bili were
normal, and abdominal ultrasound and CT were negative for
abdominal pathology, making an acute cholecystic, pancreatic,
hepatic, or obstructive GI process unlikely. A tTG-IgA was
normal, excluding celiac disease. An esophagogastroduodenoscopy
on [**7-23**] showed mild esophagitis, gastritis and duodenitis with
"feline esophagus".  An H. pylori serum antibody titer was
positive. She was prescribed PrevPac triple therapy
(lansoprazole, amoxicillin and clarithromycin) on discharge for
H. pylori eradication.  A colonoscopy on [**7-25**] showed several
small pedunculated polyps, which were excised and sent for
pathological review; there was no evidence of acute malignant
process. Her abdominal pain was thought to be due to a
combination of GERD associated with H. pylori, poor PO intake,
and some minor constipation. However, a functional GI pain
etiology could not be excluded and she was recommended to follow
up with her PCP.
.
# Protein-energy malnutrition - Patient admitted with poor PO
intake.  [**Month (only) 116**] have inadequate access to food given financial
situation. Other considerations include malabsorption, poor
intake secondary to financial considerations.  She was
determined to have moderate protein-energy malnutrition based on
low albumin on admission, which resolved after eating. A
nutrition

.
# Fatigue - The patient presented with several days of fatigue.
The differential diagnosis was broad in this elderly patient -
toxic/metabolic, endocrine, neoplasm, psychiatric
(pseudodementia vs. dementia).  The patient's TSH returned low,
making hypothyroidism an unlikley source of her fatigue.  LFTs,
B12 were within normal limits.  Age appropriate cancer screening
including abdominal ultrasound, CT, and colonoscopy did not
reveal a source for her fatigue.  It was thought that her
fatigue was most likely related to poor nutrition. She was
recommended to follow up with her PCP for further workup.
.
# Acute renal failure - The patient was admitted with a
creatinine of 2.8 (baseline 1.0).  Urine electrolytes were
consistent with pre-renal etiology.  Creatinine improved with
the administration of IV fluids to below 1.0.  Nephrotoxins were
avoided throughout admission.  Medications were renally dosed.

.
# Hyponatremia - The patient was admitted with a sodium of 129.
It was hypovolemic in origin, as it normalized with the
administration of IV fluids.
.
# Hyperglycemia - Patient presented with hyperglycemia on
admission (Glc 133) in setting of poor PO intake. No known
history of DM.  She was started on fingersticks QID with an
insulin sliding scale.  The patient was found to have an A1C of
6.0.  Blood glucose eventually fell to below 120 on maintenance
D5NS and was below 100 by the time of discharge.
.
# Eosinophilia - Her eosinophilia on CBC was mild and chronic,
and she had a full workup in the outpatient setting.  There were
no lung findings.  Stool for O&P negative.  It remained stable
throughout admission. There was no evidence of acute parasitic
or autoimmune process.
.
# Anxiety/Depression - The patient was continued on home
citalopram throughout admission.  Quetiapine was initially held
in the ICU but was restarted upon transfer to the general
medicine floor.

Discharge Instructions:
It was a pleasure to care for you during your hospitalization at
[**Hospital1 18**]. You were initially admitted to the hospital for low blood
pressure, fast heart rate and weakness. These symptoms were
consistent with a condition called "hypovolemia" or dehydration
due to poor liquid and food intake. You were given IV fluids to
correct this condition and it is now stable.
.
Once we gave you enough fluid, you had a high blood pressure,
which we treated with blood pressure medications. Please
continue to take your diltiazem and make sure to have your blood
pressure checked by your primary care doctor at your follow-up
appointment.
.
While in the hospital, you also complained of abdominal pain. We
performed multiple blood tests, radiologic scans, and endoscopic
exams to look for the cause of your abdominal pain. Your
abdominal CT scan showed no visible problems in your abdomen,
but did show a protruding disc in your spine. Your upper GI
endoscopy showed esophagitis, or inflammation of the esophagus
which connects the throat to the stomach. We started you on a
medication called prevpac to control the stomach acid and help
eradicate a GI bug called H.pylori. Your colonoscopy showed 4
benign-appearing polyps but an otherwise normal colon. The
recommendations are to have a repeat colonoscopy in 2 years from
now and have a follow-up appointment with the GI team that saw
you in the hospital.

We were concerned that you were malnourished when you were
admitted to the hospital, due to lack of access to food and
financial difficulty. We have contact[**Name (NI) **] [**State 350**] Elder
Services and you will be receiving Meals on Wheels starting this
Monday. If you have difficulty affording food, please call Elder
Services to access resources to help you.
.
You also complained of fatigue while in the hospital. We did
blood tests to evaluate your fatigue, and we believe that it is
most likely due to poor nutrition. Please follow up with your
primary care doctor if your fatigue continues.
.
Our blood tests showed that you had poor kidney function when
you arrived at the hospital, most likely due to poor liquid
intake. Your kidney function improved with good hydration.
Please continue to drink abundant liquids to protect your
kidneys.

MEDICATION CHANGES:
Please start taking prevpac for 10 days. This is a drug that
will help eradicate a bacteria that we found in your stomach
called H.pylori
While you are taking your prevpac, please do not take your
trazodone

sections.Hospital Course:
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. [**Known lastname **] is a 56 year old man with history of chronic
pancreatitis and known pancreatic pseudocyst presented with
worsening abdominal pain to OSH on [**2114-8-7**]. During his hospital
course, he was found to have worsening ascites. Conservative
management was attempted, and a drain was placed. Over time, the
fluid had increasing levels of amylase and became increasingly
biliary, and on exam, Mr. [**Known lastname **] was increasingly peritoneal.
His hospital course was complicated by worsening respiratory
status as well, and he was started on Levaquin for PNA w/
increasing O2 requirement, which, in conjunction with his
deteriorating abdominal exam prompted transfer to [**Hospital1 18**] for
further management and evaluation on [**2114-8-24**].
sections.Diagnosis:
Discharge Diagnosis:
1. Acute on chronic pancreatitis
2. Pancreatic pseudocyst
3. ARDS
4. Urinary tract infection
5. Delirium
sections.History of Present Illness:
History of Present Illness:
Mr. [**Known lastname **] is a 59 year old male with a longstanding history of
alcohol abuse and chronic pancreatitis. He was recently admitted
to [**Hospital3 7362**] for alcohol detoxification and to address his
depression and suicidal ideation. He was discharged on [**2114-8-7**]
to a homeless shelter and on [**2114-8-9**] noted the onset of severe
left-sided abdominal pain in the context of chronic epigastric
pain. He presented to [**Hospital 1281**] Hospital ED and was admitted. He
denied nausea, vomiting, fevers at the time. He did report an
episode of diarrhea prior to admission. A CT scan was performed
and identified a 10 cm pseudocyst in the tail of the pancreas.
WBC on admission was 11.3, TBili .9, alk phos 78, AST 54, ALT
25, amylase 673, lipase 114.

He was admitted to a medical floor and treated conservatively.
Repeat CT scan on [**2114-8-15**] showed increasing pleural effusions
and ascites and a paracentesis was performed on [**8-16**].  2.7
liters of bloody fluid were aspirated. The fluid studies yielded
amylase 1825, lipase 3515, 30,000 RBC, 2200 WBC, NGTD.

He required ICU transfer on [**8-17**] for increasing shortness of
breath and desaturation to 80% on nasal cannula. While in the
ICU his respiratory status worsened and he required BIPAP, with
ongoing desaturations into the 70's and 80's off of BIPAP. He
was started on levaquin and treated for possible hospital
acquired pneumonia vs. ARDS.

On [**8-18**], surgical consultation was obtained. On evaluation, he
did not complain of significant abdominal pain but did report
difficulty breathing.  At this point his WBC were 18, amylase
194, lipase 29, TBili 1.1, other LFTs normal. His abdominal exam
was reported as benign. On [**8-19**] an ultrasound-guided
percutaneous ascites catheter drainage procedure was performed.
On
ultrasound, they noted a loculated fluid collection surrounding
the spleen, as well as a focal well-circumscribed fluid
collection adjacent to the stomach. A pocket of free flowing
fluid was noted in the right lower quadrant. An 8 French pigtail
drainage catheter was placed into the RLQ with return of dark
amber fluid.

On [**2114-8-23**], the previously yellow colored drainage from the
ascites drain was noted to be notably darker in color and fluid
studies yielded 460 RBC, 400 WBC, amylase 3338, lipase 8030,
culture pending. Surgery was reconsulted for this change in
drain output and a reported increase in abdominal pain and a
worsening
abdominal exam. On evaluation at the OSH he was noted to have
rebound tenderness and guarding and worsening respiratory status
with episodes of hypotension into the 70s. He was making good
urine and remained afebrile without tachycardia. The patient was
transferred to [**Hospital1 18**] overnight on [**2114-8-24**] for further workup and
management.

On arrival, the patient was noted to be in respiratory distress
on BIPAP. His sats were in the low 90's on 100% FIO2. He stated
that his abdominal pain had been getting worse throughout the
epigastrium and right lower quadrant.

IMPRESSION:
1. Extensive bilateral pulmonary opacities, with patchy
consolidation and
apical predominant interstitial thickening with superimposed
ground-glass
("crazy paving") pattern. Differential includes pulmonary
hemorrhage and
ARDS, while infectious etiology is considered less likely.
2. Pancreatic pseudocyst arising from the pancreatic tail,
extending to
engulf the spleen, which, though enhances normally, is
compressed and
distorted by the resultant mass effect. The splenic vessels are
patent.

with a right lower quadrant drainage catheter in situ.
4. Slightly distended gallbladder with sludge in the gallbladder
neck and
prominent CBD, but without definitive wall thickening.
5. Sigmoid diverticulosis, without diverticulitis.

IMPRESSION: Large fluid collection in the left upper quadrant of

pseudocyst. Since previous study there appears to be

ligament and

Neuro: The patient was sedated as long as he required ventilator
support for ARDS. This was initially accomplished with propofol
and fentanyl (til [**8-25**]) and later fentanyl and versed (til [**8-30**]).
The patient's level of sedation was decreased as he was weaned
off of ventilator support as tolerated. On [**2114-8-30**], the patient
appeared clinically improved and he was successfully extubated
and taken off all forms of sedation. Following this, he appeared
confused and delirious. He was evaluated by psychiatry who
recommended initiation of antipsychotic and further treatment
and evaluation following discharge. He was begun on Seroquel to
good effect, with no further episodes of auditory or visual
hallucinations.  His pain was treated with oral medications once
he began tolerating PO, with occasional IV Dilaudid required for
breakthrough control. Currently tolerates PO Dilaudid, pain well
controlled.

Levophed, and fluid boluses throughout his stay in the ICU
secondary to hypotension (SBPs in 70s-80s) and low urine output.
Multiple attempts were made at weaning his pressor requirement,
without success. On [**8-26**], the patient was noted to be
tachycardic, hypotensive, and with low urine output. A Hct was
checked and found to be 25.5, and he was treated with 2 units of
PRBCs with mild improvement in his symptoms. Mr. [**Known lastname **]
continued to have borderline pressures, and given his continued
need for pressure support, a brief trial of steroids
(hydrocortisone 100 TID) was attempted from [**Date range (1) 90666**] with
good effect. Mr. [**Known lastname 26971**] blood pressures improved and he was
successfully weaned off of Levophed. From this point forward,
the patient remained stable from a cardiovascular standpoint and
required no further interventions. Given both this improvement,
as well as his lack of further ventilatory support, Mr. [**Known lastname **]
was transferred to the floor on [**2114-9-3**]. Hisvital signs were
routinely monitored, and were noted to be stable throughout the
remaineder of his hospitalization.

Pulmonary: At the time of admission, Mr. [**Known lastname **] was found to
have increased work of breathing, as well as increased
supplemental O2 requirement. A CT of his chest and abdomen was
obtained and was notable for extensive bilateral pulmonary
opacities suggestive of ARDS. Given this clinical picture and
radiographic evidence, Mr. [**Known lastname **] was sedated and intubated, as
well as treated with IV antibiotics (Zosyn and vancomycin, per
ID recommendation) for presumed infection. He was maintained on
mechanical ventilation until [**2114-8-30**] at which time the patient

ID: Mr [**Known lastname **] was initially treated with IV vancomycin and Zosyn

sections.Hospital Course:
Brief Hospital Course:
43M admitted for abdominal pain and distention found to be due
to dissecting superior mesenteric artery with thrombus in the
false lumen.  He underwent a selective mesenteric angiography,
lysis check, which was converted to an exploratory laparotomy.
During the procedure he underwent a superior mesenteric artery
thrombectomy with repair of dissection, bovine pericardial
patch, a superior mesenteric artery stent placement x2.
Postoperatively he did well and was sent to the vascular
intermediate care unit in stable condition.  His NGT was removed
over the next few days and his diet advanced.  He had a return
of bowel function (flatus) and tolerated his advanced diet.  He
worked successfully with physical therapy.  Because of the stent
he was started on clopidogrel and aspirin.  He was also started
on anticoagulation with warfarin.  He was discharged home with
therapeutic INR.  He will follow up with our service as well as
his primary care provider to manage his warfarin as an
outpatient.

sections.Hospital Course:
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to Dr.[**Name (NI) 825**] Urology service after
undergoing radical cystectomy and ileal conduit. No concerning
intraoperative events occurred; please see dictated operative
note for details. Immediately post surgery patient admitted to
the MICU for close monitoring as he had intraoperative
hypotension requiring pressors. He was stable post-operatively
and was transfused 3 units to replace blood loss. He was
transiently hypoxic. Post operative symptoms most likely related
to loss of volume or intraoperative blood loss. Anesthetics and
epidural were also a likely possibility. In the MICU his BP
stablalized and he was transferred to the floor in stable
condition. On the floor the patient's diet was advanced with the
passage of flatus. The patient was ambulating and pain was
controlled on oral medications by this time. The ostomy nurse
saw the patient for ostomy teaching.  At the time of discharge
the wound was healing well with no evidence of erythema,
swelling, or purulent drainage.  The ostomy was perfused and
patent. Patient is scheduled to follow up in one weeks time with
in clinic for wound check.

sections.Hospital Course:
Brief Hospital Course:
Mrs. [**Known lastname **] [**Last Name (STitle) **] admitted to the Trauma Surgery service after being
hit by an automobile at approximately 35 miles an hour,
sustaining the multiple injuries mentioned previously. She was
intubated in the ED because of worsening mental status. Because
of the active extravasation seen on CT, the patient was taken
emergently to IR, however no active bleeder could be found
requiring intervention. Thus, the patient was brought to the
ICU.

By systems the rest of her stay can be summarized thus:
Neurological: Because of her head injury, the patient was
started on antiseizure medication with Keppra which was
continued for 7 days as seizure prophylaxis. She did not have
any seizures during her hospital stay. She remained intubated
and sedated during her earlier hospitalization as well as after
her maxillomandibular fixation on [**2129-4-3**] where she was nasally
intubated. After extubation, her mental status improved and she
was clear and coherent, alert and oriented on discharge. She
will follow up with Cognitive Neurology as an outpatient.

Respiratory: She was intubated at [**Hospital1 18**] for deteriorating mental
status and protection of airway. After the OR on [**2129-4-3**], she
remained nasally intubated until [**2129-4-8**]. This was due to the
extreme swelling after her surgery, requiring treatment with
steroids to reduce swelling as well as diuresis. She underwent
an uneventful extubation and remained stable respiratorily until
discharge.

Heme: Upon admission, she went to IR for attempted embolization
of the bleeding artery seen on CT. In the ICU, her hematocrit
drifted down over the course of days and she was transfused
three units in total during her stay. Her hematocrit stabilized
at 20 and then began rising again prior to discharge. At
discharge she was hemodynamically normal, non-tachycardic and
without orthostatic hypotension.

Ortho/Mandible: On [**2129-4-3**], she underwent reduction and fixation
of her mandible fracture with maxillomandibular fixation. She
was also seen by orthopaedics and treated nonoperatively for her
various fractures. Because of concern for quadriceps tendon
rupture, she had MRIs of her legs which showed no rupture. She
is full weight bearing on the left and touch down weight bearing
on the right secondary to her right first toe proximal phalynx
fracture.

ENT: She was seen by ENT upon presentation and just prior to
discharge for her Left temporal bone fracture and concern for a
middle ear injury. She was given cipro ear drops. She will
follow up with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 3878**] for an outpatient audiogram and
follow up for the temporal bone fracture.

Nutrition: A dobhoff was placed at bedside for tube feeds on
[**2129-4-3**] and this was used until she was extubated and able to
tolerate thin liquid diet. Tube feeds were stopped two days
prior to discharge. At discharge, she had adequate PO intake and
will go home with boost plus supplements in addition to a full
liquid diet. The dobhoff was removed prior to discharge.

Optho: because of blurry vision in her R eye, an opthalmology

sections.Hospital Course:
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to [**Hospital1 18**] Surgical ICU after beign
trasnferred from an OSH where he was intubated and placed [**First Name5 (NamePattern1) **]
[**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] cervical collar after a fall. He remained stable in the ICU
overngiht and scans of his head, face, sinus, mandible, and
torsos were obtained. He was found to have multiple nasal
fractures and an occipital bone fracture in addition to his
intracranial blood. On the mornign of [**7-30**] he was deemed fit for
extubation and it was noted after conversation with his wife
that he had within at least the last 24 hours if not more
recently used heroin. As a result the ICU placed him on
Methadone [**Hospital1 **] for withdrawl prophylaxis. Pt had a repeat CT that
evening which showed stable parafacline SDH and R frontal
contusions.

He was extubated without incident.  On [**7-31**], he was transferred
to floor in stable condition.  Social work was consulted on [**8-1**]
due to active heroin abuse however patient refused to meet with
social work.  He also refused the option of methadone clinic
initially stating that he wasn't allowed back to the
[**Location (un) 89246**] clinic and subsequently stating that it
wouldn't help his addiction.  It was explained to him that
without adequate followup in methadone clinic or with a
specialist he would not be given a prescription for methadone.
He intitially entertained the option of a suboxone treatment
program but then refused based on his HIV medication status.  He
became increasingly agitated and demanded to be discharged as
soon as possible.

At the time of discharge the patient is afebrile, VSS, and
neurologically stable.  Patient's pain is well-controlled and
the patient is tolerating a good oral diet.  He was cleared by
PT for discharge home in stable condition and will follow-up
accordingly.

sections.Hospital Course:
Brief Hospital Course:
SUMMARY

Ms. [**Known lastname 101629**] had a long course. Initially admitted with hypoNA and
hypoK, she went on to develop severe fluid overload requiring
intubation and CRRT as well as a UTI and presumptive PNA treated
with broad spectrum antibiotics. Her fluid overload was
complicated by SVT that prompted initiation of selective beta
blockade and a cardiac evaluation (negative nuclear stress). She
went on to tolerate aggressive diuresis and was discharged

By Problem

# Hyponatremia [**1-20**] to Cirrhotic hemodynamics, fluid overload
  Hypotension, Shock with septic physiology

  On admission, Na+ was 120 and she was asymptomatic. Initially
treated with fluid restriction with little success, then with
Tolvaptan 15mg then 30mg with increases of [**12-20**] mEq per day,
plateauing at 126.  On [**7-28**] She was hypotensive to the 90's with
orthostasis.  She was transferred to the [**Month/Year (2) **] surgery team
and SICU on [**7-30**] for dyspnea and hemodynamic management. her
respiratory status declined to the point of requiring intubation
(see respiratory failure). She required the support of 2
pressors. Despite no clear  source of her septic response, with
supportive care and antibiotic treatment, the patient's
hemodynamics and respirtory systems stabilized. On [**8-4**],
Ceftriaxone, vanco, and flagyl due to her hypotension and
worsening leukocytosis. On [**8-5**] fluc was started.  There was not
a clear source of the patient's hypotension and leukocytosis.
On [**8-12**], antibiotics were stopped. The patient was then
transferred back to the floor in stable condition.

# Respiratory Failure [**1-20**] fluid overload
  Hepatic Hydrothorax
  Oliguric renal failure

  On admission [**2167-7-21**] she was short of breath, but saturating
well 95-98% on room air.  She became breathless with 5-7 word
sentences.  A paracentesis removed one liter of fluid on [**7-25**],
without much resolution of symptoms, an ultrasounds on [**7-27**] found
insufficient ascites to tap. Thoracetesis on [**7-29**], removed 900cc
of pleural transudative fluid. CXR on [**7-29**] for SOB found
pulmonary edema with sats 90-92%.  After albumin/lasix/albuterol
sats improved to 94-96% on 3L NC and creatinine rose to 1.4.
Her saturations were at 90-92% sitting, and on standing her sats
dropped to 85%. She was transferred to the ICU where she
required intubation and CRRT. On [**8-4**], the patient failed BiPAP
and was intubated. Bronch on [**8-6**] showed minimal secretions.  As
more fluid was removed and her hypotension improved, the patient
was weaned to PS from CMV.  On [**8-13**], the patient was extubated.
On [**8-8**], the patient tolerated being 2.6L negative on CVVHD
along with BP support on pressors.  The patient tolerated having
2L removed daily.  By [**8-12**], the CVVHD was running even. On [**8-14**],
CVVHD was stopped the patient's urine output slowly increased.
Upon return to the floor, she tolerated aggressive diuresis with
midodrine for BP support.

# Atrial Fibrillation
  Patent Forament Ovale
  Normal EF, Normal Nuclear Stress

  On SICU admission, the patient had a stable blood pressure.
On [**8-1**], the patient went into atrial fibrillation with a rapid
response. Cardiology was consulted and recommended continued
diuresis and to add metoprolol 12.5 PO BID for rate control.  On
[**7-31**] an echo cardiogram (TTE and TEE) was performed which showed
normal systolic function and a PFO. Cardiac enzymes were
negative x 3.  The patient went into intermittent A. fib. On
[**8-3**], the patient was started on low dose dopamine with no
cardiovascular or renal response. On [**8-4**], Neo-synephrine was
started and the lopressor was d/c'ed. Vasporessin was also
started for hypotension. Due to presumed sepsis, the
Neo-synephrine was transitioned to levophed.  Pressors were
weaned over the next few days. The patient received intermittent
IV and PO lopressor for bouts of A. fib. On the floor, she was
maintained on 12.5 mg Metop tartrate TID. A nuclear stress was
negative, save for persantine induced symptoms. Cardiology
recommends continuing beta blockade through her [**Month/Year (2) **]

# Hypokalemia

  She was repleted with KCl and her potassium corrected and was
stable for the remainder of the admission.

# Cirrhosis, likely from NASH (T2DM, hx of obesity, htn,
dyslipidemia)

  The patient was continued on tube feeds (isosource 1.5). She
was continued on lactulose and ursodiol, gastric varices, and
ascites.

# T2DM

  The patient is on an regular insulin SS for her DMII. In the
ICU, on [**8-7**], an insulin gtt was started to improved glucose
control.  The insulin gtt was weaned and the patient was started
on NPH and sliding scale which she tolerated well.

# UTI

  The patient was on ciprofloxacin for a klebsiella UTI.   The
patient was then started on daily ciprofloxacin for SBP
prophylaxis.

sections.Hospital Course:
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. [**Known lastname 39392**] is an 89 yo male w/ PMHx sig for atrial fibrillation
on
[**Hospital 197**] transferred from [**Hospital3 2783**] with R frontal and
temporal DHs and R occipital IPH in the setting of
supratheraputic INR, thought to be related from unknown trauma
vs hypertension.

# Subdural hematomas: The patient was found to have R frontal
and temporal subdurals and R occipital IPH in the setting of
supratherapeutic INR.  This was reversed with Vitamin K and FFP.
  He was followed by NS, who determined that no surgical
intervention was needed at this time and recommended that Keppra
be started for seizure prophylaxis.  They had initially
recommended restarting ASA, but given the extent of his bleeds
and discussion with his family, it was decided to hold
anticoagulation until further evaluation with NSG in 1 month.
The patient continued to have L sided weakness and L hemineglect
on transfer to the floor, so Neurology was consulted. A repeat
MRI revealed no evidence of acute infarct and stable size of his
bleeds.  They felt that his bleeds could explain his previous
hemineglect.  On repeat examination, Neurology felt his hemi
neglect had and did not feel further intervention was needed.

He is scheduled for NSG follow up in 1 month with repeat CT
scan.

# Atrial fibrillation: The patient has a h/o afib, for which he
was on Coumadin and Toprol 25mg PO daily. He had an episode of
afib with RVR on [**2124-10-20**], which responded well to Diltiazem
10mg IV. His Toprol dose was increased to 50mg PO daily with
good effect. HR on discharge 88.

# UTI: The patient had a UCx that showed infection with
Enterococcus. The patient was started on a 14 day course of
Ampicillin. He has 10 days remaining in his course.

# Severe AS/Pulm HTN: The patient had an ECHO, which showed
severe aortic stenosis with valve area 0.8-1.0 cm2 and severe
pulm HTN. He will need close follow up by his outpatient
cardiologist, Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1313**], [**Telephone/Fax (1) 39393**]

progression of your bleed.  You were transferred to the general
medicine floor on [**10-19**] and did well.  The neurology team also
came and evaluated you and requested an MRI which showed no new
strokes and the previous bleeds were stable.

The following changes were made to your medications
1.  Hold Coumadin and other blood thinners until your visit with
Neurosurgery in 4 weeks.
2.  Start Keppra 750mg by mouth twice daily to prevent seizures
until your visit with Neurosurgery
3.  Take Ampicillin 500mg by mouth every 6 hours for the next 10
days for a urinary tract infection
4.  Tylenol 325-650mg by mouth every 6 hours as needed for pain
5.  Increase Metoprolol succinate from 25mg to 50mg by mouth
daily
6.  Discontinue Lasix 20mg until re-evaluation by your primary
care physician.

If you experience worsening headache, increased weakness,
difficulty speaking or slurring your speech, bowel or bladder
incontinence, shortness of breath, chest pain, fevers, chills,
or any other concerning symptoms, please call your primary care
physician or return to the emergency department.

It was a pleasure meeting you and taking part in your care.

sections.Hospital Course:
Brief Hospital Course:
OPERATIONS DURING ADMISSION
[**10-5**]  Flexible bronchoscopy with aspiration cervical
mediastinoscopy, median sternotomy and repair of innominate
artery.

CONSULTATIONS DURING ADMISSION
Cardiology, [**10-8**]

PATHOLOGY:  Mediastinal Lymph Nodes
II.  4L (C-D):
Metastatic, poorly differentiated non-small cell carcinoma.
III.  2R (E):
Metastatic, poorly differentiated non-small cell carcinoma.
IV.  Level 1 (F-I):
Metastatic, poorly differentiated non-small cell carcinoma.

# Flexible bronchoscopy with aspiration cervical
mediastinoscopy, median sternotomy and repair of innominate
artery:
The patient is a 75 yo male w/RUL biopsy-proven non small cell
lung ca who was admitted on [**10-5**] for bronchoscopy and
mediastinoscopy for staging purposes.  The patient was taken to
the operating room on [**10-5**]; the mediastinoscopy was complicated
by significant scarring (probably from infiltrative tumorous
process) in pretracheal space with a subsequent tear in the
inominate Artery requiring emergent sternotomy with primary
repair.  Fortuantely, the patient remained hemodynamically
stable throughout the operation with SBP consistently above 100;
he did have EBL 1000, u/o 220, ivf 2500, 5 units of blood were
transfused.

Postoperatively the patient was taken to the SICU and extubated
where he remained in good condition overnight.  His Hct remained
stable at 28.

# Rapid Atrial Fibrillation:
On POD2 the patient went into rapid atrial fibrillation.  He was
placed on a diltiazem drip and converted to sinus rhythm
overnight.  The following day his drip was discontinued, he was
placed back on his home dose of atenolol and started on lasix.
The evening of POD3 he converted back to atrial fibrillation
with regular ventricular rate. He was changed to lopressor and
diltiazem with rate control.
Cardiology was consulted, who recommended lopressor TID and an
Echocardiogram.  The Echo revealed:  EF 55% with normal left
ventricular function. (see report).

# Right sided effusion
The patient was brought to the SICU with a mediastinal [**Doctor Last Name **] in
place; this was discontinued on POD2.  On POD4 the patient was
noted to have a developing right sided effusion.  IP was
consulted for thoracentesis.  They drained 340 ml of bloody
discharge.

# NSCLCA
Unfortunately, the mediastinal lymph nodes were positive for
metastatic disease. He was schedule for follow-up with the
multidisciplinary onocology team as an outpatient.

sections.Hospital Course:
Brief Hospital Course:
This is a 52 year old woman who had the worst headache of her
life on [**2-17**]. Her roommate claimed that the patient was in and
out of consciousness and she had a  syncopal episode and was
intubated by EMS. A head CT was performed at the OSH which
revealed a SAH and the patient was given 50g of mannitol and 1g
of dilantin then transferred to [**Hospital1 18**] for further neurosurgical
intervention. Upon arrival to [**Hospital1 18**], patient was taken for a CTA
scan and then a formal angiogram.  While in angiogram she had a
PCOMM aneurysm coiled.  She remained intubated overnight and was
extubated the next am.

Her exam improved steadily and her diet was advanced. She was
monitored in the ICU for 6 days. During that time she underwent
CTA/CT on [**2-21**] after a period of confusion she was found to have
no vasospasm. She remained hemodynamically stable during this
stay and was given IV fluids prophylactically. On [**2-23**] she was
transferred to the neuroscience floor. On [**2-24**] she complained of
headache and a CTA was repeated. This showed some increase in
vasospasm and she was transfered to the SDU. On [**2-25**], patient
reported headache but remained stable, she remained in the step
down unit. On [**2-26**], TCDs were performed which showed moderate
vasospasm in the R MCA. Patient was started on IVF at 100cc/hr.
Hip X-rays done on [**2-27**] showed no fractureExam was stable.
Casework say her for assistance with son at home. On [**2-28**],
patient appeared depressed but refused psych

* You may take your prescribed pain medication for moderate to
severe pain. You may switch to Tylenol or Extra Strength Tylenol
for mild pain as directed on the packaging. Please note that
Percocet and Vicodin have Tylenol as an active ingredient so do
not take these meds with additional Tylenol.
* Take prescription pain medications for pain not relieved by
tylenol.
* Do not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking any
narcotic pain medication.
* Take Colace, 100 mg by mouth 2 times per day, while taking the
prescription pain medication. You may use a different
over-the-counter stool softener if you wish.
.
Call the office IMMEDIATELY if you have any of the following:
* Signs of infection: fever with chills, increased redness,
swelling, warmth or tenderness at the surgical site, or unusual
drainage from the incision(s).
* A large amount of bleeding from the incision(s).
* Fever greater than 101.5 oF
* Severe pain NOT relieved by your medication.
.
Activities:
* No strenuous activity
* Exercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining,
or excessive bending.
* It is recommended that you wear a soft collar when out of bed
for 4 weeks.

such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil or Ibuprofen etc
